required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Stroke Prevention in the Wisconsin Native American Population
clinical_study.official_title: Stroke Prevention in the Wisconsin Native American Population

brief_summary.textblock: This project will develop a "Stroke Awareness Team" including training of Oneida Health Service Coaches working in partnership with the UW team for a population-based health awareness program. This team will develop a series of Oneida Nation Healthy Living and Stroke Awareness Events (from now on health events) to provide education as to the severity of the problem as well as our standard therapies for lifestyle change and risk factor avoidance. This will include education of the healthy members of the tribe including the children to identify signs of stroke and TIA in their elders as well as to develop healthy lifestyles at the earliest of ages to influence the elders to modify their risks.

detailed_description.textblock:
The study will enroll 100 high risk tribe members and 20 low stroke risk tribe members. Each of these will be further studied for their atherosclerotic load by ultrasound assessments (noting plaque presence, plaque area and measurements of plaque stability or instability during pulsation [carotid strain imaging] of the carotid and vertebral arterial systems. Enrolled participants will also receive assessment of stroke-related vascular cognitive decline, serum analysis for glucose, cholesterol, microRNA and key proteins felt to be biomarkers of stroke.
These high risk participants will be divided into two groups, stratified by gender, age, history of cerebrovascular events, and the presence or absence of atherosclerosis in their carotid bifurcation including equal numbers of participants that in spite of high risk, have not yet deposited plaque.
One group will receive advice about standard therapy and information as to a health awareness and the risk factor guidelines. Study team physicians will provide advice about standard therapy based on participant risk factors. Health awareness and risk factor guidelines refer to AHA educational materials; these educational documents will be provided to participants, if relevant. These educational materials address topics such as cooking healthfully, improving cholesterol levels, the impact of cholesterol on risk, the importance of physical activity, reducing high blood pressure, and the effects of smoking. These tools provide information on the health effects of a medical condition or habit, and then provide tips on how to improve health. For example, the "How Can I Reduce High Blood Pressure?" educational document, first provides readers with information on what health conditions high blood pressure can cause, and then provides steps on how to reduce high blood pressure. These steps include advice on how to lose weight, limit sodium, and limit alcohol. These documents will be provided based on physician assessment of participant Stroke Risk Quiz. Participants can take these educational documents and their Stroke Risk Quiz results to their PCPs. If there are incidental findings during examination, these will be communicated in writing by the study team physicians. A letter will be provided to the participant as well as their PCP if indicated in their consent form.
The other group will receive the same plus intensive initiation of the American Heart Association Guidelines for Management of Risk Factors with quarterly group and weekly, individual face-to-face coaching meetings on lifestyle change and adherence to treatment. A subset of 10 participants in the intensive intervention group will also undergo an annual reassessment at the Year 1 timepoints, including health assessment, health history, carotid ultrasound, cognitive testing, and continued coaching. These participants will be selected based on their carotid strain values. Low risk participants (Group 3) will undergo the same study events as Group 2, except without receiving advice about eliminating stroke risk factors.
At the end of 2-year follow-up, all groups will be reassessed for adherence to the program, atherosclerotic plaque progression or regression and its stability, serum biomarker response to therapy interventions, successful risk factor modification, vascular cognitive decline and incidence of stroke and TIA. Intention to treat analysis will estimate the efficacy of health coaching and will use G-estimation to correct for issues of non-compliance and discontinuation. Groups will be compared for change in both risk factors and outcomes.
Intensive intervention coaching sessions will occur at least quarterly. Health coaches will contact participants weekly to check-in on the status of goals and provide support. Health coaches will contact participants using the manner most appropriate for each individual (phone, email, or in-person). The aim is to plan health coaching sessions as often as necessary in order to help participants meet the goals that they set at the beginning of the study. For some individuals, meeting goals may require weekly coaching sessions. For other individuals, it may require less coaching. Ideally, subjects will be interacting with the same coach throughout their participation. However, in the event of vacation, illness, or other circumstances, the other health coach may reach out to participants to check-in or may conduct coaching sessions.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Number of Participants that meet AHA Simple Rules for Diastolic Blood Pressure
primary_outcome.description: Number of Participants with diastolic blood pressure < 90 mmHg

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Number of Participants that meet AHA Simple Rules for Systolic Blood Pressure
primary_outcome.description: Number of Participants with systolic blood pressure < 140 mmHg

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Number of Participants that meet AHA Simple Rules for Total Cholesterol
primary_outcome.description: Number of Participants with total cholesterol < 200 mg/dL

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Number of Participants that meet AHA Simple Rules for Low Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol (LDL-C)
primary_outcome.description: Number of Participants with LDL-C < 100 mg/dL

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Number of Participants that meet AHA Simple Rules for High Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol (HDL-C)
primary_outcome.description: Number of Participants with HDL-C > 60 mg/dL

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Number of Participants that meet AHA Simple Rules for Blood Sugar
Change in Number of Participants that meet AHA Simple Rules for Body Mass Index (BMI)
primary_outcome.description: Number of Participants who improve BMI

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Number of Participants that meet AHA Simple Rules for Smoking Status

primary_outcome.description: The Consortium to Establish a Registry for Alzheimer's disease-Neuropsychological Assessment Battery (CERAD-NAB) is a cognitive assessment of episodic memory by asking the participant to recall 10 unrelated words before and after a 5-10 minute delay. Scores are from 0 to 10 depending on the words recalled. Interpretation of scoring is encoded relative to education and age.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Pulsatile Strain in Arterial Plaque

other_outcome.description: Levels of serum microRNA are associated with increased stroke risk. This will be measured via blood draw at baseline and 3 years.
Gal-3 is a circulating protein associated with cardiovascular risk. This will be measured via blood draw at baseline and 3 years.
DPPIV is a circulating protein associated with cardiovascular risk. This will be measured via blood draw at baseline and 3 years.

arm_group.description: age ≥ 55 with MORE than three of the following risk factors: History of TIA/Stroke History of Coronary Artery disease History of Hypertension and/or current elevated blood pressure History of Diabetes Current smoker BMI ≥30

age ≥ 55 with MORE than three of the following risk factors: History of TIA/Stroke History of Coronary Artery disease History of Hypertension and/or current elevated blood pressure History of Diabetes Current smoker BMI ≥30

age ≥ 55 with LESS than three of the following risk factors: History of TIA/Stroke History of Coronary Artery disease History of Hypertension and/or current elevated blood pressure History of Diabetes Current smoker BMI ≥30

intervention.description: The following assessment will occur: health assessment, blood pressure, BMI, history TIA/stroke, blood mRNA and protein analysis, ultrasound, cognitive assessment, stroke education, intensive coaching face-to-face. Furthermore, this group will receive intensive initiation of the American Heart Association Guidelines for Management of Risk Factors with individual face-to-face coaching meetings on lifestyle change and adherence to treatment on at a least quarterly basis.
The following assessment will occur: health assessment, blood pressure, BMI, history TIA/stroke, blood mRNA and protein analysis, ultrasound, cognitive assessment, stroke education.
Control participants will undergo the same study events as the Low Risk group, except without receiving information and advice about eliminating stroke risk factors.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Participants receiving health care through the Oneida Health Council Program
- Participants deemed to be at high risk for stroke by modified Framingham assessment of medical history, including cerebral cardiovascular symptomatology, hypertension, diabetes, smoking, BMI
- Willingness to participate in the study, including two-year follow-up
- Controls will be selected using the same criteria with the exception that upon screening, they are not deemed to be at high risk for stroke.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Presence of established dementia
- Inability to participate in physical and exercise programs due to preexisting disability
- Illiteracy
- Prior carotid procedure altering ultrasound finding
- Presence of medical condition precluding participation or follow-up over a two-year period of time.

patient_data.ipd_description: Following transparency and reproducibility guidelines (NIH NOT-OD-15-103), the data resulting from this research proposal will be made publicly available. This will help ensure that other researchers are able to reproduce and/or extend our findings, and will enhance the scientific rigor of this proposal. Data will be made available for download to any individual or organization who requests data and abides by a data-sharing agreement that will be developed. This agreement will require that the data be used solely for research, that individuals or organizations secure the data using conventional electronic safeguards, and that once data analysis is complete, the data be destroyed. In general, data acquired in this study will be made available publicly after initial key manuscripts have been accepted for publication. Manuscripts will include relevant methodological details to allow for reproducibility by other researchers and the ability to extend or findings.
